[Statement 1]: No action documents reported evidence on public education campaigns reducing plastic litter ingestion by river dolphins in South America.
[Statement 2]: The available evidence on education for marine and freshwater mammals showed only changes in participant intentions and behaviors.
[Statement 3]: Changes in participant intentions and behaviors included an increased willingness to support marine conservation.
[Statement 4]: Changes in participant intentions and behaviors included an increased willingness to cut fishing nets to save entangled dolphins in Peru.
[Statement 5]: Available evidence on education for marine and freshwater mammals reported no population or health outcomes.
[Statement 6]: Additional education programme evidence concerned terrestrial carnivores in South Africa.
[Statement 7]: Additional education programme evidence concerned household outreach on garbage and bears in the USA.
[Statement 8]: Additional education programme evidence did not concern dolphins or plastic ingestion outcomes.
[Statement 9]: A review from North America stated education alone was not sufficient to change behavior without complementary measures.
[Statement 10]: The review from North America did not provide outcomes for dolphins or plastic ingestion.
